lines.text: So a tough loss for the Indians as Pedro Cerrano doubles off a pigeon and is tagged out while administering CPR before the tying run could score. Funny game ain't it Monty?
Well at least the bird survived.
Who cares? It's a rat with wings.

[drunk]
So, Hiroshi "Kamikaze" Tanaka, recently of the Tokyo Giants, knocks himself cold for the second time this week. Maybe in Japan, that's actually better than catching the ball. Personally, I think he's just trying to get out of the lineup.
As General Manager of this team, I demand to know when I'm getting a start.
There's an old timer's game coming soon.
Come on, you're not going to let her get you down, are you? You guys won last year just to spite her. Maybe, she's what we need.
Oh, Skip, they were a different team last year.
Taylor, it's not your job to make excuses. That's all you guys do good! It's either a *leg* thing or a *spiritual* thing, or a *psychological* thing, or a *heart attack*!
Who used heart attack?
Me.
[collapses from a heart attack]
You know, Rick, I may have to use you tomorrow in the late innings. Pitching staff's pretty overworked.
Yeah. So? I'll be ready.
Ready, huh? Ready to what? Run and hide if the game's on the line?
I don't get it, Jake. What's your problem?

You're the problem. You used to be the toughest guy on this team. Now you're trying to prop yourself up with the right woman or the right shrink or God knows what else. You want to be a major league pitcher? You have to find something in yourself that yours and nobody else's. You had that once, Rick. And if I were you, I spend the rest of the night trying to find it again. Without it, you're no good to me or the team.
[Jake leaves]
What an asshole. What an amazing asshole. I thought he was my friend. Why is everybody so threatened by me improving myself?
[Looks in the mirror, sighs]
What an asshole.
They're going to send me back to Omaha and I don't even live there!
[Willie is in his first at-bat and points his bat to the left field fence]
And look at this. Willie Mays Hayes is calling his shot.
All right Willie! Right here!
What's he pointing at? Does he know somebody out there!
Hayes steps in and gets his pitch. There's a swing and it's going toward left. And it is...
[Willie hits the ball and the left fielder catches it at the warning track]
Not quite gone.
That had to be the wind.
It must have been the wind.
OK, we won a game yesterday. If we win today, it's called "two in a row". And if we win again tomorrow, it's called a "winning streak"... It has happened before!

[after Rube get's hit by a pitch]
Hayes, go run for Rube.
My leg's hurtin'.

[stands up]
I'll run.

[sits Dorn back down]
Rube's hurting worse than you. Now get in there!

[pointing to Vaughn]
If the gutless wonder doesn't have to pitch than why should I have to run?

[gets up]
Who are you calling a gutless wonder, tin man?
Tin man?
[gets up limping]
I got a genuine leg injury here, pal.
And that limp is the best acting you've done all year.
[turns around to leave]

[turns Vaughn around]
Well at least I don't have some cover girl dragging me around by my johnson.
[Vaughn tackles Hayes as he walks away, starting a brawl]

[sees that Rube's injured]
Lucky son of a gun. At least you ain't gotta hang around to play the second game, right?
[walks away]

Hey, Willie. Willie! I can't believe you said that. Shit! I talked to a boy in the bleachers the other day who hales from downtown. He told me the most grass he's ever seen in his whole life is the patch that we get to play on everyday.
[to the team]

We're in the goldarn major leagues, boys. I don't know about any of you, but I've been waiting my whole life to get here. And I'll be damned if I'm gonna act like my best pig died just cuz we ain't doin' so good. I love to play baseball and I'll bet, somewhere along the line, you all did too.
[turns to Jake]

I'm ready to play ball if you need me. My Dad figured I wouldn't amount to much except... well, I never came up with anything, but I know I can play ball a little. And a day of playin' ball is better than what most people have to do for a living. So just put me in someplace.
[Rick Vaughn is pitching to Jack Parkman during practice]
What do you call that garbage?
It's my eliminator. I've got another pitch. You get a piece of it, I'll let you name it.
[Vaughn pitches and Parman hits the ball out of the park]
I'd, uh, call it the masturbator.
you can't live with them, and they can't pee standing up.
Hey, Cerrano. I'm on the rooster.
Rube, you look at Playboy all the time, don't you?
I don't just look at it. I read the articles.
Sure you do.
I do. I especially like it when they mention the girls' interests, like Betsy loves surfing.
You even memorize them?
Yep. I guess I do.
Bingo.
I'm the only winner on this team. The rest of 'em, they're losers. Either by choice, or by birth.
Wow, Willie's really got some power.
Off a guy who'll be bagging groceries in a couple of weeks!
[after Hayes calls a shot to left field and flies out to left for the second time]
You know, he could be pointing at the left fielder.
[first lines]

Hello everybody. Harry Doyle here, welcoming all you Wahoo maniacs to the year's first session of Tribe Talk. As you know, the Indians had a Cinderella season last year. Despite the fact that *toxic* owner Rachel Phelps wanted the team to lose so she could move it to Florida, the Indians won the American League East for the first time since divisional play began. Rachel's gone now, thank God, having sold the team to retired Indian third baseman Roger Dorn, after a long, hard fought series of negotiations.
[flashback to negotiations]
Mmmight be willing to go as high as a hundred.
120? Rachel, you just started at 110!
Rachel, this isn't fair!

[desperately begging]
130!

[immediately gives in]
We'll take it!
Oooh, you're good Dorn.

[scene returns to radio show]
Even with Dorn in the owner's box, the Indians are solid favorites to repeat in the East, and to go all the way to the World Series. And why not? Look at the lineup we have coming back. First of all, the Cuban Crusher, the voodoo man with a bad attitude, Pedro Cerrano. Even though his training methods were a little unusual, Pedro finished in the top five in homers, RBI's, slugging percentage and total baldness. Also back is centerfielder Willie May Hayes, who came out of nowhere to lead the league in great catches and stolen bases. We're told he starred in an action movie during the offseason, where he not only did his own stunts, but even his own acting. And don't forget about catcher and team leader Jake Taylor. Despite chronic knee problems he had a fine season, and beat out the bunt that drove in the run that won the division title. And finally one of the brightest young stars in the game today, Rick "Wild Thing" Vaughn. Vaughn began the season in the uniform of the California Penal League and had some control problems early on. But with the help of a pair of black hornrims, he went on to set a Major League record for strikeouts in a season by an ex-carcy. All in all, things couldn't be looking better for the Tribe.
[Jake and Rube are discussing Rube's problems as a catcher]
What exactly is your problem?
Well, uh...
[a limo's horn sounds and the limo pulls up]
Well, uh... hell that's the biggest damn car I ever saw.

[an entourage of eleven people gets out of the car, followed by Willie]
Say Jake! Oh-hooo! Ha-ha!
Who are they?

[stunned]
They are our centerfielder.
Mr. Vaughn, I thought you were starting tonight.
I did.
Oh, sorry. I didn't tune in until the 2nd inning.
Well he's gonna walk Beck to pitch to Parkman obviously Taylor's thinking... I don't know WHAT the hell he's thinking.
[Harry is drunk when he introduces the game]

Hello, Tribe fans, welcome to Major League Baseball... sort of. The attendance today is 14 hundred and 12. Most of them left after that 10 run inning the Red Sox put up. Take over Monty, I'm in the bag.
[head hits desk]

[as the outfielder catches the ball, the crowd is disappointed]
Fly ball... Caught!
He'll need a rocket up his ass to catch that one; that baby's out of here.
You know, you have no... you have no...
[looks in translation book]
Marbles!
Marbles?
Marbles! You have no marbles!
Marbles?
[gets mad]
Huevos?
Mr. Parkman, your a great ballplayer and I just like to say, your standing on the tracks and the train's coming through butthead.
[Vaughn is lamenting the long home run he gave up in his first game]
Oh, yeah? Name one park in America that ball wouldn't have gone out of.
Yellowstone.

[goes up to bat]
Parkman, my good friend. How you doing?
Look at the scoreboard, Buddha, I'm doing just fine.
that was beautiful.
[hits home run]
Not as beautiful as that though!
[laughs]

[to Parkman after rounding the bases]
Look. At. The. Scoreboard. Now, Grasshopper!
My momma always said, "It's better to eat shit than to not eat at all."

[after Rube reaches base on a severely sprained ankle]
Well, The Indians have a runner. I think I'll wet my pants.

[drunk]
Bottom of the 9th, Cleveland down 1 to nothing. Baker steps in he's 0 for... I don't know. Who cares? The pitch
[Baker hits a slow roller and limps down the line]
Baker swings and sends a *real screamer* towards short. Ah wrap up with it, fires to first... and Baker beats it with a head-first slide. So the Indians have a runner. I think I'll wet my pants.

[Parkman visits Vaughn at the mound after Vaughn gives up three straight hits]
What?
WHAT? They're hammering the slow crap. Think your arm can handle the strain of throwing this guy a fastball?
Look, I'll throw it, you just make sure you catch it.
I will if it ever gets to me.

Well fans, Roger Dorn has done a little redecorating around the ballpark. The outfield walls now look like the yellow pages. And any of you folks having trouble finding a good proctologist, might want to come down here and check out the area around the 375 foot sign. As for the game, we've got a real nailbiter here tonight. It's a lot closer than that 11-2 score.
Cerrano doing some interesting limbering up exercises in right.

[covers microphone]
What a pansy!
[batter hits a fly ball]
Here's a fly ball hit to right. Easy play for Cerrano, under it now, and makes the catch...
[ball hits Cerrano's glove and goes over fence]
No, that ball is off his glove and outta here! So credit Cerrano with an RBI, and that play could be a finalist in the Trojan-Enz Boner of the Week Award.

Tribe fans, we're one out away from our second consecutive divisional title. Rick Vaughn has gone 3 and 2 to Mel Koskie. Here's the pitch. Ball four, and he walked him. That's going to bring the tying run to the plate for the Toronto Blue Jays. A little excitement here at the end. I know I wouldn't have it any other way, and I'm sure you folks feel the same.
[takes out a bottle of Jack Daniel's whiskey]
Rube, what's going through your head just before you throw the ball back to the pitcher?
I'm thinking, "Damn, I don't want to screw this up."
Well, what are you thinking when you throw a strike to nail the runner down at second base?
Well, I, I'm not thinking nothing. I just throw it.
You see what I'm getting at?
You want the pitcher to pitch from second base?

[frustrated, blank look]
Oooogh.
We're in the top of the 9th inning leading 10-7, bases loaded, two down, and Rick Vaughn has come on to try to nail it down against Felipe Aguilar, a dangerous right-handed batter. Here's the pitch.
[Aguilar crushes it]
Aww, shit.

[in unison]
No! No! No!
If that's not Shaquille O'Neal in left, that baby's outta here.

[catches the ball in the stands for a home run]
NO! You rotten bums! You overpaid weenies! Mild thing, you make my butt sting! I *detest* you! You're all garbage! All of ya! Back up the truck! Back it up!
Vile thing, you make my butt sting! I detest you! You're all garbage, all of ya! Back up the truck, back it up!

Rick Vaughn gets the starting call today. We're told he matured a lot over the winter. Apparently he's bathing now. Congratulations, Rick. As you know, Monte, Vaughn's been working on a couple of new pitches, the Eliminator and the Humilator, to complement his fastball, the Terminator.
I heard that.
Dynamite drop-in, Monte. That broadcast school has really paid off.
You know I used to hate Parkman when he was with the A's. It's amazing how a new uniform can change your attitude about a guy.
[covers Mic]
He's still a dick.

My God! Good news fans, the Indians are showing signs of life for the first time in weeks. As a matter of fact they appear to be beating the crap out of each other. It looks like Willie Hayes is trying to hit Rick Vaughn, and why not, everyone else in the league does. Hayes swings and misses. I don't know Monte, it looks like Vaughn is carrying his left a little low. This could hurt him in the later rounds.

[Rick Vaughn shakes off fastball]
He's afraid of his fastball.
He's screwed.
You're screwed Vaughn.

[in Japanese]
He's dicked.

[after find out Phelps has bought the team]
Miss Phelps.
[Speaking in Japanese]
May you be mounted by a rabid dog. You're lower than rat excrement.

Hey. Ya know Ricky, breaking up with a girlfriend can be a very painful thing. But it don't have to keep ya down for long. I mean, let me tell ya something from my own personal experience. I've never had a regular girlfriend like you, but I did get kicked in the balls once by a mule. Now, I thought I would be hurting for the rest of my life. But you know what happened the very next week?
What?
My momma died. Hell, after that, I didn't care no more about my balls hurtin'. You see what I'm gettin' at?
Told you I wasn't gonna slide!
You got a long way to go peckerhead
That's Mr. Peckerhead to you, PAL!

[talking about the promo for his film]
That spot didn't show the real dramatic parts, like when they kill my boa constrictor and I vow revenge.
Oh.

[seeing Rick Vaughn coming out of the dugout and heading into the bullpen]
Vile Thing, I think I *loathe* you! You did think I'd abandon you, did you Vaughn? You human piece of cow slop! You big steaming pile of mastodon dung! Bring out the pooper scooper! You bush league no-talent flash in the pan choke artist! Huh?
[Vaughn starts to walk back to the dugout]
Hey, where you going, Vaughn, huh? You looking for your Terminator, Vaughn? Yeah, you go back in there, Vaughn!

[after knocking down Baker, who loses the ball]
Welcome to the Bug Leagues, Hayseed. Next time, don't stand on the tracks when the train's coming through.

[when Parkman is up to bat, facing Vaughn]
Mr. Parkman, you're a good ball player, but I want to say, that you're standing on the tracks and the train's is about to come through, bonehead.
When the tough get goin', go an' get tough.

[Tosses baseball up in the air as he lays on the couch]
You think you can help me with my fastball, Doc?
We'll have to deal with some deeper issues first.

[Continues tossing ball]
I don't have any deeper issues. I like to keep things right on the surface.

[Catches the ball]
Well sometimes there are little surprises. Tell me, Rick. What goes through your mind when you throw your fastball?
I wonder if it's gonna end up in the catcher's mit or some guy's den.
Did you used to think this way?
I didn't used to think at all. It takes a lot out of you, you know?
Well then, Rick, let's get down to it.
[Closes pad and takes off glasses]

The real problem here goes back to when you stole that car. You wanted to be caught, didn't you? Punished. Otherwise you wouldn't have thrown the 0 and 2 fastball to Fields when everybody knows he'll chase the 2 strike curveball in the dirt.
I had already thrown him two curveballs. The second one, he hit 436 feet foul.
Better than 520 feet fair.

[about a pitch he threw and a hitter hit it for a home run]
. I threw him a 87 MPH fastball, and he crushed it. Last year, I averaged 96, now when I reached back it's just not there. I can't believe that I forgotten how to throw heat.

[Drinking whiskey, and sounding drunk]
Hello, fans. Welcome back to major league baseball, sort of. Today's attendende is...
[Looks at his paper]
1,214. Most of them left after the 10-run inning the red Sox put up, take over Monte, I'm in the bag.
[Passes out on the desk]

[Slightly excited]
Me?
[Sees Cerrano hit a line drive]
Fly ball,
[sees the Red Sox right fielder catch the ball]
caught.
[Then, sees the Indians fight each other]
Hey, wake up.
What? My god. the Indians are showing signs of life in weeks.
[Willie and Rick are about to punch each other]
It seems that Willie Mays Hayes is trying to hit Vaughn, who blames him, everybody else in the league does.
[Rick tries to puch Willie , who ducks out of the way]
Vaughn is hanging his left a little low, this could hurt him in the later rounds.

[Seeing Vaughn coming back into the dugout]
Hey, didn't I tell you to go to the bullpen.
We're down by 10 runs, Jake.
Well you can still get some work in.
I've had enough of that maniac out there.

[after seeing Rube Baker get hit with a pitch]
Hayes, go run for Rube.
My legs hurtin'.

[Stands up]
I'll run.
[Jake sits him down]
Rube's hurting worse than you. Now get in there.
The Gutless Wonder doesn't have to pitch. Why should I have to run?
Who you calling a Gutless Wonder, Tin Man?
Tin Man? I got genuine leg injury here, pal.
That limp is the best acting you've done all year.

[Grabs Vaughn by the arm]
Well at least I don't have some Cover Girl dragging me around by my Johnson.
I've got your timing now. I bet you don't have enough hair on your ass to throw me another.
Well, here it comes, Parkman. The ol' number 1, the Terminator. You get a piece, you can rename it.
Just think, after this game we'll be going to the World Series.
Yeah, in Chicago.

[after Taylor signals to the bullpen]
He wants the righty, he wants the Mild Thing, the grab your throat and choke thing.
Shove it up your ass, lard mouth.
Oh my god, Oh my god!

[On the phone]
Listen, Meg, I'm thinking of coming to LA. I don't know if Rick and I are good for each other right now. I mean, the team is showing signs of life, but his ERA is over 6 and he hasn't got a clue on how to get it back on track. It's depressing. Serious with Vaughn? He's a lot of fun, but I need someone with a little more class.
[Finds Rick waiting downstairs]
My shrink was sick.
You were so wonderful out there, Rick. The General Cereals reps are here.
Great game, Rick. We'd like to offer you a 3 year...
Sorry, fellas, but you got the wrong guy. I'm sure you make a great cereal, but I like my hair the way it is. I don't get up in time to eat breakfast anyway.
Rick, what are you saying?
You're a great gal, Flannery. Much too good for me. Take a hike.
How can you sell my best player without asking me?
I'm on my ass, tapped out. I'm even going to be able to make next month's payroll.
Geez.
But I didn't sell Parkman outright. I got you an outfielder. He used to play for the Giants.
Franklin?
Not those Giants.
Parkman, I saw your little interview in this morning's paper. You're benched for two games and if you ever rip any of your teammates like that,

[interrupting]
Save your breath.
What did you just say?
You oughta listen to the radio more, Lou. Your biggest gun just got traded to Chicago. As a matter of fact, your only gun. Au revoir.
Say Parkman, I just want to say that even though we're competing for the same position, I'm glad they signed you. You're a good ball player.
Cut the crap, Taylor. I don't like you and you don't like me. Just don't blame your bum knees when I take your job.
Ooh, must be tough to be old.

[in Japanese]
Let's beat their brains in!

[to Rachel]
Miss Phelps!
[in Japanese]
May you be mounted by a rabid dog. You're lower than rat excrement.

[visiting Lou in the hospital]
Hey, you're lookin' good, Lou.
Forget about me. I'm fine. You gotta talk to the team, Jake. Give 'em hell. Let 'em know they're too damn good to roll over and play dead.
Will do, Skip. And, hey, we'll win this one for you.
[goes to leave]
Hey, Taylor.
Promise me one thing.
Sure. What?
When you talk to the team, don't give 'em one of them "let's win one for Lou" corny speeches. I couldn't stand that.

[after the Indians take the lead, Lou is using his Transistor radio to listen to the game]
Now we're starting to roll, boys.
Are you alright, Mr. Brown?
Uh, yeah. I love this British stuff.
[the scene goes to the small TV which has 2 British women drinking tea]

[after Parkman hits a home run, putting the White Sox Back in the Lead]
Damn.
[Looks to his nurse]
This is tragic stuff.
[after Ceranno hits a home run, putting the Indians back in the lead]
Good one, Pedro. Big knock, baby. Big knock

[after the Indians win the ALCS, Lou is jumping up and down on his bed]
Mr. Brown. What are you doing?
I love this shit, I may move to England
[falls into his bed in excitment]

[about Willie Mays Hayes]
Went to see his movie but it was only out for two and a half hours. I was told, however, that it was in focus.
